Effects of a regional decollement level for gravity tectonics on late
Neogene to recent large-scale slope instabilities in the Foz do
Amazonas Basin, Brazil

Extra sets of 2D multi-channel seismic and chronostratigraphic data allowed us to undertake analyses of
source to sink processes and triggering mechanisms of the gigantic megaslides previously documented
off the NW and SE steep slope settings of the Foz do Amazonas basin. As these megaslides comprise two
sets of stacked allochthonous masses within the Upper Miocene-Quaternary sedimentary record, they
are now described as Mass-Transport Complexes (MTCs) and have been renamed the Amapa Megaslide
Complex (AMC) and the Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide Complex (PMMC). Individual megaslides of both MTCs
can mobilize up to kilometre-thick sedimentary series as allochthonous masses with distinct ﬂow di-
rections, degrees of sediment disruption and internal coherence. Megaslides spread downslope over
areas as large as thousands of km2, attaining dimensions comparable to the world's largest mass-
transport deposits. Among all the megaslides, the basal and largest AM1 megaslide (AMC) stands as a
quite unique example of mass-transport deposit in the basin, interpreted as a dominant carbonate
allochthonous mass sourced from a mixed carbonate-siliciclastic platform. The instability was probably
triggered between the late Miocene and the end of the Early Pliocene by the gravitational collapse of the
mixed platform under its own weight, after successive subaerial exposures which generated kar-
stiﬁcation processes. Siliciclastic-type megaslides, on the other hand, are all sourced from large upslope
slide and/or rotated blocks (up to 60 km wide in the case of the PMMC). The detachment of upslope
blocks was triggered by structurally-induced seabed movements during the Mid Pliocene-Pleistocene (in
the case of the PMMC) and during the Pleistocene (in the case of the AMC). All mapped features support
the interpretation of sedimentary blocks which have undergone long lasting deformation, having been
variably folded and faulted by the sliding along an overpressured condensed section (H3 horizon). H3
horizon equally acts as the upper decollement level for the gravity tectonic system that operates on the
regional scale of the Foz do Amazonas basin. In such a context, the results of this study evidence complex
links between variable modes and scales of gravity processes (gravity tectonics and MTCs emplace-
ments), all induced by instability created from a condensed section prone to produce pore ﬂuid over-
pressure. And yet, seismic attributes of the decollement H3 across the slope, characterized by a reﬂector of
negative polarity of high amplitude, indicate that the potential for similar large scale sediment failures
continues to exist across the AMC and PMMC.

1. Introduction

The Foz do Amazonas basin (Amazon Mouth basin) is the largest
offshore basin located on the Brazilian Equatorial Atlantic margin.
This basin has been the target of systematic exploration by oil
companies in recent decades, due to the potential occurrence of oil
plays in the deep-water marine setting. The Amazon Deep-sea Fan
(referred to hereinafter as the Amazon fan) stands as the main deep
basin sedimentary feature, built out as a prominent, thick sedi-
mentary prism, of about 10 km in thickness according to Brand~ao
and Feijo (1994) and Figueiredo et al. (2007). Mass-transport de-
posits have also long been reported as important stratigraphic el-
ements in the margin sedimentary construction, especially in the
Upper Quaternary Amazon fan (e.g., Damuth and Embley, 1981;
Damuth et al., 1988; Flood et al., 1991; Piper et al., 1997; Maslin
et al., 2005).
In most studies of the upper 500e800 m layers of the Amazon
fan the occurrence of mass wasting has been correlated either
with climate-induced processes, gas hydrate instability or sedi-
ment loading (e.g., Damuth and Embley, 1981; Damuth et al., 1988;
Flood et al., 1991; Piper et al., 1997; Maslin and Mikkelsen, 1997;
Pirmez and Imran, 2003; Maslin et al., 2005). However, the Up-
per Cretaceous to Quaternary stratigraphic section of the basin
also glides along multiple decollements in a linked extensional-
compressional system (Cobbold et al., 2004; Silva et al., 2009;
Reis et al., 2010). An upslope set of extensional faults and huge
downslope fold-and-thrust belts root into three main basal weak
levels. Thrust structures can reach the sea ﬂoor, forming scarps as
high as 500 m (Reis et al., 2010). In such a deformational context,
Reis et al. (2010) showed that gravity tectonics has also acted as a
signiﬁcant preconditioning parameter for slope failures: a link has
been established between compressional deformation of fold-and-
thrust belts in the central Amazon fan and the onset of triggering
conditions

Quaternary.
The occurrence of megaslides has also been reported in Foz do
Amazonas basin (Araújo et al., 2009; Silva et al., 2010), recorded as
gigantic and multiple slide masses which, unlike the Upper Qua-
ternary MTDs previously mapped in the area (e.g., Damuth and
Embley, 1981; Damuth et al., 1988; Flood and Piper, 1997; Maslin
et al., 2005), occur only off the steep margin settings both to the
NW and SE of the Amazon fan (Fig. 1). These megaslides, named
the Amapa Megaslide and the Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide, occur as
stacks of large-scale and thick mass-transport deposits (individual
thicknesses of up to 1000 m). As the megaslides are located along
portions of the steep continental slope of the basin, and under
sedimentation rates considerably lower than those of the central
basin region of the Amazon fan, Silva et al. (2010) ascribed the
main inducing factor for these mega-events to high slope gradi-
ents. However, due to the limited database these allochthonous
masses were neither stratigraphically constrained nor have their
internal structures and features yet been analyzed in detail until
now. In this context, further details as to how these mega mass-
transport deposits occur and how they are stratigraphically orga-
nized are not only necessary but also fundamental for exploration
purposes.
In the present study, we have integrated additional 2D regional
seismic lines and well data to supplement the database of Silva
et al. (2010), in order to clarify internal seismic facies, structures
and the stratigraphy of the megaslides of both complexes. This
procedure now provides the most detailed correlation framework
with chronostratigraphic signiﬁcance for the Amapa and the Para-
Maranh~ao Megaslides. It has also allowed us to propose their
source
to
sink

as
well
as

main
triggering
mechanisms.
2. Regional setting

The Foz do Amazonas basin evolved within a context of both
wrenching tectonics, kinematically related to ancient transform
movements especially along the Saint Paul Fracture Zone (e.g.,
Matos, 2000; Moulin et al., 2010), and compressional tectonics,
related to the history of the Andean uplift, which reshaped the
catchment basin of the Amazon river (e.g., Hoorn et al., 1995;
Latrubesse et al., 2007; Figueiredo et al., 2009). In terms of crus-
tal structures, the Ceara Rise stands as an outstanding aseismic
ridge in the western Equatorial Atlantic located approximately
800 km east of the Amazon river mouth (Fig. 2). The top of this rise
lies at about 3000 m below sea level, located just beyond the edge
of the Amazon fan and surrounded by a seaﬂoor of an average
depth of about 4500 m. The Amazon fan deposits lap onto the base
of the western side of the Ceara Rise at about 4200 m water depth
(Curry et al., 1995; Dobson et al., 2001).
The base of the stratigraphic succession of the Foz do Amazonas
basin is composed of Neocomian to Albian ﬂuvio-deltaic, lacustrine
and marine strata, inﬁlling pull-apart half-grabens (Brand~ao and
Feijo, 1994; Figueiredo et al., 2007). Open marine clastic deposi-
tion started during the Eo-Albian (c. 102 Ma) with the deposition of
deep-water mudstones and siltstones that lasted until the Neo-
Paleocene (Limoeiro Formation; Fig. 3). The Cenozoic sedimentary
history of the basin was dominated, from the late Paleocene to the
late Miocene (~61.7e~9.5 Ma), by carbonates which were periodi-
cally disrupted by siliciclastic deposition (Wolff and Carozzi, 1984;
Gorini et al., 2014), resulting in the buildup of a mixed carbonate-
siliciclastic platform as thick as 4000 m (Marajo and Amapa For-
mations), laterally equivalent to deep-water calcilutites and mud-
stones (Travosas Formation; Fig. 3).
During the development of the mixed carbonate-siliciclastic
platform, the basin experienced a series of drowning phases
intercalated with major regressive phases (Figueiredo et al., 2007).
The last and most important drowning phase occurred during the
Middle Miocene, reaching the maximum transgression during the
Langhian (c. 15.2 Ma). Following this Middle Miocene maximum
ﬂooding, coastal depositional systems prograded (Marajo Forma-
tion; Fig. 3), while the carbonate platform continued to develop on
the external continental shelf. This drowning phase lasted until the
late Miocene when lower sea levels exposed, karstiﬁed and eroded
the carbonate platform culminating in the deﬁnitive cessation of
carbonate sedimentation at c. 9.5 Ma (Gorini et al., 2014). As
recently shown by Gorini et al. (2014), until the late Pliocene
increasing siliciclastic input into this basin occurred as dominantly
prograding shelf clinoforms developed across the proximal basin,
whereas higher siliciclastic input into deep-water settings occurred
during the Quaternary.
2.1. Gravity tectonics in the Foz do Amazonas Basin

The entire gravity system across the Foz do Amazonas basin
(Silva et al., 1999, 2009; Cobbold et al., 2004; Reis et al., 2010;
Perovano et al., 2011) affects an area as large as 40,000 km2 (Reis
et al., 2010), across the shelf downslope to ~2100 m (Figs. 2 and
4). Silva et al. (1999) were the ﬁrst authors to identify a linked
extensional-compressional system gliding over two surfaces of
weak overpressured shales, likely induced by progradation and
overloading of the Amazon fan: a lower decollement placed at the
top of the early Cretaceous Marine Megasequence (c.100 Ma; Fig. 4)
and an intermediate decollement located at the base of the
Paleocene-Eocene Marine Megasequence (c. 65 Ma; Fig. 4). Silva
et al. (2009) and Reis et al. (2010) reﬁned the gravity tectonic
structural framework previously mapped in order to evaluate how
gravity
tectonics

and

affected

(Buried Mass-Transport Deposits) from Damuth et al. (1988); the Amapa Megaslide and the Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide mapped at the scale of the Foz do Amazonas Basin and re-

architecture. The occurrence of a third upper decollement level
(horizon H3 in Fig. 4B) was identiﬁed at the base of the Amazon fan,
along which part of the fan's stratigraphic succession has been
thrusting, decoupled from more ancient fold-and-thrust belts
which detach along the lower and intermediate decollements
(Fig. 4). Towards the ﬂanks of the Amazon fan, where the Amapa
and Para-Maranh~ao megaslides occur, the upper decollement level
accommodates proximal normal faults (extensional domain) but
without any basinward thrusting system, thus not constituting a
typical gravity tectonic nappe composed of upslope extension
linked to downslope compression (Fig. 5).
2.2. Mass-transport deposits in the Foz do Amazonas Basin

The upper 500e800 m of the Amazon fan (late Pleistocene)
consist of channel-levee complexes interbedded with recurrent
MTDs. Remobilized sediment masses (slumps, slides and debris
ﬂows) can be as large as 15,000 km2, reaching individual thick-
nesses of up to 200 m (e.g., Damuth and Embley, 1981; Damuth

et al., 1988; Piper et al., 1997; Flood and Piper, 1997; Maslin et al.,
2005), as occurs in (Fig. 1): the Western Superﬁcial Mass-Transport
Deposits (WMTD), the Eastern Superﬁcial Mass-Transport Deposits
(EMTD), the Unit R Mass-Transport Deposits (URMTD) and the Bot-
tom Mass-Transport Deposits (BMTD).
Gas hydrates destabilization, higher sedimentation rates during
lowstands, and the rise of hydrostatic pressure during trans-
gressions and sea-level highstands have been considered the main
causes of slope instabilities and mass movement initiation for these
Upper Pleistocene MTDs on the central Amazon fan (e.g., Damuth
and Embley, 1981; Damuth et al., 1988; Flood and Piper, 1997;
Piper et al., 1997; Maslin and Mikkelsen, 1997; Maslin et al.,
2005). More recently, however, Reis et al. (2010) evidenced that
signiﬁcant volumes of mass-transport deposits, geographically
coincident with those Upper Pleistocene MTDs of the central fan,
had their triggering mechanisms preconditioned by the gravita-
tional compression of gravity-tectonic fold-and-thrust belts. Thus,
this study has documented for the ﬁrst time a clear link in the area
between two modes of gravitational processes in the Foz do

Amazonas Basin e gravity tectonics and mass wasting.
Occurrences of megaslides have also been reported by Silva et al.
(2010) and Araújo et al. (2009) on the ﬂanks of the Amazon fan, this
time involving thicker and more ancient sedimentary sections. On
the southeastern ﬂank of the Amazon fan, the Para-Maranh~ao
Megaslide was mapped as a unique allochthonous mass of up to
1000 m thick spreading across an estimated area of 90,000 km2,
and composed of a combination of debris ﬂows, slide blocks and
compressively-deformed sedimentary units (Fig. 1). On the north-
western ﬂank of the fan, the Amapa Megaslide was recognized as
a succession of superimposed allochthonous masses, recurrent
through the late Neogene sedimentary section and covering a total
estimated area of 80,000 km2 (Fig. 1). Higher slope gradient values
off these steep margins were considered to be the main inducing
factor to have initiated these mass wasting mega-events. A regional
interaction of gravity tectonics and mass wasting processes has also
been suggested as another possible triggering mechanism, but
limited data coverage did not allow the authors to explore the
details of the entire gravity tectonic framework of the Foz do
Amazonas basin further.
3. Database and methods

The dataset for this study included approximately 20,000 km of
2D multi-channel seismic data, extra exploratory well data recently
made available for our research group by the Brazilian of Petroleum
and Gas Agency (ANP) (Fig. 2).
The seismic dataset concerns a super-regional seismic grid of
100 km spacing and an industrial seismic grid of 10e20 km spacing
(Fig. 2): the ﬁrst consists of the LEPLAC Survey lines collected at 13 s
recorded time intervals by the Brazilian Navy (vertical resolution of
circa 20 m); the second grid, collected at 10 s recorded time in-
tervals (vertical resolution between 10 and 20 m) was provided by
ANP, together with litho- and chronostratigraphic data from 2 in-
dustry wells (wells P1 and P2; Fig. 2). Complementary mono
channel seismic data (up to 9 s penetration) acquired during VEMA
Cruise 31 (Leg 06) was also integrated into the data base (http://
maps.continentalshelf.org/geodas/V3106.htm) in order to tie in
biostratigraphic data from the DSDP site well 142 (Hayes et al.,
1972) represented as well P3 in Fig. 2.
The regional bathymetric data are taken from the General
Bathymetric Charts of the Oceans e GEBCO (www.gebco.net),
whereas newly available higher-resolution bathymetry on the

Hydrography and Navigation, Brazilian Navy, from compilation of
different sources, including PETROBRAS and the Geophysical Data
System e GEODAS (www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/geodas).
Seismic data were interpreted on the software Kingdom Suite®.
A seismic sequence stratigraphic framework was undertaken based
on the available exploratory wells data, coupled with data pub-
lished in earlier papers (e.g., Hayes et al., 1972; Silva et al., 1999;
Brand~ao and Feijo, 1994; Figueiredo et al., 2009, 2010). This strati-
graphic framework allowed the mapping, for the ﬁrst time, of
regionally persistent horizons across the entire deep basin with the

objective of establishing some age deﬁnition of the emplacement of
megaslides. Horizons of interest in the deeper basin were also tied
to the main stratigraphic sequences and stratigraphic events of the
margin, according to material recently published by Gorini et al.
(2014). For all the calculations of sediment thickness related to
mass-transport deposits, an interval seismic velocity value of
1800 m/s was considered.
The criteria used to recognize mass transport deposits were the
occurrence of seismic facies and features indicative of sediment
failures and remobilized sediment deposits, such as those identi-

4. Results

The results presented below are organised into three main
sections, addressing different geological aspects that present
additional information for the comprehension of megaslide oc-
currences across of the Foz do Amazonas basin: the Slope
morphology (subsection 4.1); Basin-scale chronostratigraphic corre-
lation (subsection 4.2); and the Architectural analysis of megaslide
complexes (subsection 4.3).
4.1. Slope morphology

The morphology of the central Foz do Amazonas Basin is greatly
affected by the Amazon fan deposition, whereas much steeper
gradients are observed both on the NW and SE continental slopes
adjacent to the fan, which are characterized by narrower conti-
nental margins (Fig. 6).
In the central basin, the gradient is rather subdued by the thick
sedimentary sequences responsible for the Amazon fan's con-
struction: the regional gradient on the upper fan is of the order of
0.9; whereas on the middle fan the regional gradient is slightly
smoother (of the order of 0.8; proﬁle B in Fig. 6). On the other
hand, the NW continental slope of the basin has the highest relative
gradient values observed throughout the continental margin (up to
5.8), followed by a reduction of gradient values from the depth of
2000 m basinwards (0.4e0.25; proﬁle A in Fig. 6). The SE conti-
nental slope of the basin is equally rather steep, presenting relative
gradient values up to 4.0, followed by a gradient reduction
basinward from the depth of 3000 m (0.4e0.5; proﬁle C in Fig. 6).

4.2. Basin-scale chronostratigraphic correlation

In the absence of basin-scale stratigraphic correlations, it was
necessary to undertake a stratigraphic study of the Foz do Ama-
zonas deep basin, in order to relate the development of the meg-
aslide complexes (MTCs) to the major depositional intervals and
regional deformational events. This analysis was performed by the
interpretation of the extra well data available for the present study
(P1, P2 and P3; Fig. 2), correlated with chronostratigraphic well
data from previous chronostratigraphic and biostratigraphic pub-
lished data (e.g., Hayes et al., 1972; Figueiredo et al., 2009, 2010;
Gorini et al., 2014). Based on such correlations we were able to
extend a series of Cenozoic time horizons from the shelf downslope
into the deeper basin (Fig. 7), which allowed us either to re-
interpret or to trace the major basin-scale stratigraphic surfaces
which play a role in mass wasting processes:

4.3. Architecture and stratigraphic analysis of megaslide complexes

The new database available for this study allowed us to re-
interpret in further detail the megaslides previously documented
by Silva et al. (2010) across the NW and SE ﬂanks of the Amazon fan,
including
the
recognition
of
other
regional
occurrences
of
allochthonous masses.
As the megaslides are two sets of stacked allochthonous masses
within the Upper Miocene-Quaternary sedimentary record, they
are best described as Mass Transport Complexes (MTCs), and here-
after renamed as: the Amapa Megaslide Complex (AMC) and the
Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide Complex (PMMC).

4.3.1. The Amapa Megaslide Complex
The Amapa Megaslide Complex (AMC) corresponds to a series of
stacked megaslides, named Amapa after the adjacent coastal
Amapa State in northern Brazil (Silva et al., 2010). The AMC is
composed of six
major individual megaslides
encompassing
different stratigraphic levels, interlayered with undisturbed depo-
sitional intervals which display either continuous or strong re-
ﬂectors (Fig. 8). Several other smaller MDTs could also be identiﬁed,
but because they could not be correlated across the study area
(because they were too thin or because of the lack of regional
extent) they are not described in this paper. An acronym was
assigned to each mappable megaslide, according to its position in
the stratigraphic section (from the most ancient to the most recent;
Figs. 8 and 9 and Table 1): AM1 (Amapa Megaslide 1); AM2 (Amapa
Megaslide 2); AM3 (Amapa Megaslide 2); AM4 (Amapa Megaslide
4); AM5 (Amapa Megaslide 5) and AM6 (Amapa Megaslide 6).
AM1 to AM6 are marked by seismically well-deﬁned basal
decollement surfaces (Fig. 8), whereas their disturbed masses show
seismic evidence of distinct degrees of displacements and disrup-
tions, as indicated by a set of variable acoustic seismic facies types,
such as: internal transparent to chaotic facies; or a combination of
chaotic facies with local interbedded facies (Fig.10). The megaslides
lie either directly on the top of each other, as AM4, AM5 and AM6
do, or may be separated from each other by continuous units of

strong plan-parallel reﬂectors: as thick as 300 ms as in the case of
that between AM2 and AM3; or as thick as 700 ms, as in the case of
that between AM1 and AM2. These continuous strong plan-parallel
units were seismically interpreted as a combination of turbiditic
and hemipelagic deposition (Figs. 8 and 9B).
AM1 is the basal megaslide, lying directly on horizon H3 (Fig. 8).
It is also the largest megaslide mapped throughout the basin,
extending downslope for about 280 km in a general SeN direction,
presenting a maximum width of c. 250 km and covering a total area
of approximately 67,000 km2 (Table 1 and Fig. 9A). The depositional
area of AM1 is located some 40e50 km downslope from the
headscarps of the younger AM2 (Figs. 8 and 9), being mostly
characterized by highly chaotic to transparent seismic facies which
thicken

basinwards
and
bulge

(maximum thickness of c. 778 m), creating a major positive topo-
graphic feature over the coeval seaﬂoor.
Clear headwall scarps related to AM1 are difﬁcult to identify
(Fig. 8), as no scars cutting into siliciclastic series in a plausible
location and with plausible dimensions were found in spatial
relation to this huge allochthonous mass. However, across the
northwestern steep margin, AM1 deposits are found some 100 km
downslope from a large erosive area clearly recognizable along the
slope, which merges downslope with the basal horizon H3, indi-
cating that AM1 could have slid away downslope from the
dismantling of the mixed carbonate siliciclastic platform, leaving
behind a large evacuation scar (Figs. 8B and 9A). In some parts of
the NW basin, slope scarps are even replaced directly downslope by
detached blocks of high amplitude reﬂection, in continuity to
which we ﬁnd the transparent AM1 megaslide seaward from the
fold-and-thrust belt system (Figs. 11 and 9A). Internal huge blocks
of comparable very high amplitude reﬂections (up to 15e20 km
wide) are preserved as pre-failed stratigraphic layering within the
transparent AM1 allochthonous mass (Figs. 8, 10A and 11).
On the other hand, the upper part of the AMC is composed of a
stack of ﬁve closely-layered megaslides (AM2-AM6; Figs. 8 and 9B).
Headwall scarps related to AM2-AM6 are clearly identiﬁed. The
northwestern slope area is dominated by a steep NW-SE-oriented
faulted-erosive scarp (scarp A on Fig. 8), which extends laterally
for about 160 km, between c. 450-1200 m water depth (mean
vertical relief of 750 m). On the lower slope lies a large rotated block
(some 30 km wide) affected by numerous normal faults. AM2-AM6
headscarps are found just downslope from the rotated block as

~150e300 m cutting into undisturbed layers. We can thus recog-
nize a sharp transition between upslope undisturbed plan-parallel
siliciclastic units and the chaotic and/or transparent seismic facies
depicting these megaslides downslope (Fig. 8). We can also observe
that:

(1) AM2 stands as one of the largest siliciclastic units of the AMC.
It exhibits a tabular-like geometry (Table 1 and Fig. 9B). Its
internal seismic character is dominated by transparent
facies, with the presence of local parallel-layered facies
interpreted as preserved internal blocks, while its distal
depositional units are extremely chaotic. These seismic and
architectural characteristics point to a high degree of sedi-
ment disruption, supporting the interpretation of AM2 as
predominantly liqueﬁed mass ﬂows (Figs. 8 and 9B);
(2) AM3 and AM4 slide along basal decollement surfaces that
shift upward or downward in the stratigraphy, depicting
staircase morphologies (Fig. 8). AM3, the smallest megaslide
in area (Table 1 and Fig. 9B), is dominated by chaotic facies
and is substantially thicker close to its upslope limit, where
traces of previous stratiﬁcation were preserved (Fig. 10B).
AM4, the largest siliciclastic megaslide of the AMC (Table 1),

also exhibits dominant internal chaotic facies, but contains
widespread internal preserved slid blocks. The degree of
fragmentation is highly variable, with the largest coherent
blocks presenting widths of up to several kilometers. Its basal
shear surface can be continuously traced with remarkable
spatial variations and geometries. Locally, it ramps the stra-
tigraphy up and down to create a series of staircase-like
geometries (Figs. 8 and 10B and C). Both AM3 and AM4
bulge up above the regional undeformed slope datum at
some point of their downslope spread (Fig. 8). These seismic
and architectural characteristics support the interpretation
of AM3 and AM4 as predominantly debris-ﬂow deposits
containing higher content of chaotic and more viscous sed-
iments in comparison to AM2. No internal imbricate struc-
tures are seismically visible at their borders, indicating thus
that no signiﬁcant lateral or frontal conﬁnement is present;
(3) AM5 differs from all other siliciclastic megaslides since it
does not present any clear headscarp. Like AM2, AM5 slides
down along a very ﬂat basal decollement surface and presents
external tabular-like geometry (Figs. 8 and 10C and Table 1).
It also displays a combination of transparent and chaotic
facies interspersed with internal deformed blocks (Fig. 10C).
These seismic and architectural features indicate thus a de-
gree of sediment disruption comparable to that of AM2;
(4) AM6 corresponds to a stratigraphic succession that slid along
a general ﬂat basal decollement surface, which shifted slightly
downwards (Fig. 8 and Table 1). It also displays dominant

chaotic facies interspersed with frequent internal deformed
blocks, but AM6 bulges up midway to its downslope move-
ment (Figs. 10B and C), until it thins again to disappear
completely in continuity with non-deformed layered re-
ﬂectors (not shown in Fig. 8). This megaslide does not pre-
sent distal imbricate structures (thrust sheets), suggesting
that no signiﬁcant frontal conﬁnement is present. However,
compressional features are observed midway along its entire
extent, taking the form of thrust sheets that ramp up por-
tions of a basal preserved block, forming a compressional
ridge of about ~5 km width (Figs. 9B and 10C). These seismic
and architectural characteristics point to predominantly
debris-ﬂow but with some degree of viscosity, represented
by the great number of internal preserved blocks.

4.3.2. The Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide Complex
Our results evidenced that the Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide, pre-
viously described as a single megaslide by Silva et al. (2010), is
actually part of a thicker megaslide complex, composed of 4 main
allochthonous masses. An acronym was assigned to each megaslide
recognized and mapped during the present study (from the most
ancient to the most recent; Figs. 12 and 13 and Table 2): PM1 (Para-
Maranh~ao Megaslide 1), PM2 (Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide 2), PM3
(Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide 2) and PM4 (Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide
4). Similarly to the AMC, several smaller MTDs have also been
identiﬁed on different seismic lines, but they are not correlated

The PMMC exhibits a particular architecture, being composed of
a large upslope cohesive slide block with smaller runout distances
when compared to the main distinguishable MTDs downslope
(PM1, PM2, PM3 and PM4; Fig. 13). The slide block is composed of
highly reﬂective though sometimes discontinuous internal re-
ﬂectors organised in a series of closely-spaced tilted and rotated
compartments limited by synthetic normal listric faults. This large
slide block (as thick as 1000 km) involves about 12,500 km2 of
remobilized sediments (Fig. 12), which has the seismically well-
deﬁned horizon H3 as a basal decollement (Fig. 13). Upslope from
the displaced block lies a steep NW-SE-oriented erosive scarp
(Scarp 1 on Fig. 13) which extends laterally for about 180 km along
the upper slope, at between ~200 and 900 m water depth (mean
vertical relief of 1000 m). This scarp is the product of gravitational
instability having its origin in normal listric faulting along the high-
gradient slopes in the area, partially as a result from the detach-
ment of the large block which slides along the horizon H3 (Fig. 13).

The downslope limit of the displaced block is a second major
prominent scarp, erosive in nature, derived by successive slide-offs
and disruption of the distal portion of the slide block (Scarp 2 in
Figs. 13 and 14A). Scarp 2 runs along about 260 km across the lower

Remobilized masses PM1, PM2, PM3 and PM4 were all sourced

PM1, PM2, PM3 and PM4 are marked by seismically well-

indicated by a variable set of acoustic features, that can be grouped
into distinct seismic facies types, such as: internal transparent to
chaotic facies; imbricates composed of closely-spaced thrust
sheets; and a combination of chaotic facies with local interbedded
facies (Fig. 14).
The set of PM1-PM3 megaslides is much smaller in extension
and thickness than PM4, and ﬂows in a general SW-NE direction

PM4, the topmost megaslide, is a much larger unit which ex-
tends downslope in a general E-W direction for about 600 km into
the neighboring Para-Maranh~ao basin, covering a total area of
approximately 118,700 km2, involving a total remobilized volume
of c. 33.000 km3 (Fig. 12B). PM4 remobilized sediments thin
signiﬁcantly from about 1000 me100 m towards its outermost
eastern distal portion located in the Para-Maranh~ao basin, given
that the landslide mass tends to migrate to higher stratigraphic
horizons (Figs. 14B and 15). Its maximum thickness (c. 700 m) is
reached midway along its whole extension (Fig. 14). Upslope, PM4
is dominated by chaotic to transparent facies indicating a high
degree of sediment disruption, seismically compatible with debris
ﬂows (Fig. 14A). Further downslope, however, it is composed of a
large series of imbricate thrusts as wide as 50 km that in map view
form crescent-shaped compressional structures which eventually
reach the seaﬂoor to form a topographic high relief (up to 100 m
high; Figs. 12B and 14B). These structures clearly indicate that this
landslide mass has undergone signiﬁcant frontal conﬁnement
(Fig. 14). Similarly, near its eastern end in the Para-Maranh~ao basin,
PM4 exhibits pressure ridges (Figs. 12B and 15). On the other hand,
some distal portions although initially ramping up and exhibiting
some degree of buttressing, eventually spread over undeformed
sea-ﬂoor units in an unconﬁned way (Fig. 15).
PM4 is, throughout, overlain by a continuous layer of about
150e200 m thick, characterized by in situ discontinuous plane-
parallel reﬂectors, reﬂecting its original layering preserved on the
top of the MTD. This upper inﬁlling layer is nevertheless marked by
small irregularities of the seaﬂoor and is eventually lifted by the
distal pressure ridge as well (Figs. 13 and 14).
5. Discussion

Our results evidence that the Foz do Amazonas basin represents
in many instances an outstanding setting for mass movement
investigation on passive margins, because of the dimensions of
MTCs, associated source to sink processes and the triggering
mechanisms involved in the slope failure processes.
5.1. Ages and dimensions of the MTCs in the Foz do Amazonas basin

The MTCs mapped in this study on the NW and SE ﬂanks of the
Amazon fan have evidenced that large MTDs have been more
recurrent and widespread than previously reported in the basin
(Figs. 16 and 1). Besides that, the present study has also provided
further detail concerning both the dimensions and ages of the two
MTCs in comparison to previous studies: MTDs of the AMC all
together constitute a total volume of remobilized sediments of
approximately 27,832 km3, whereas the MTDs of the PMMC have a
total volume of approximately 44,443 km3. The two largest meg-
aslides of each complex alone (AM1 and PM4, respectively; Tables 1
and 2) are comparable to the world's largest mass-wasting deposits
(Fig. 17). Further, the two MTCs show that large MTDs have been
recurrent throughout the basin since at least the late Miocene, thus
standing out as essential architectural elements of the basin's
stratigraphy (Figs. 16 and 18).
Age correlations, together with the reﬁnement of the in-
terpretations of the seismic facies and stratigraphic origins of each
component of the PMMC and the AMC, allowed us to evidence that
these MTCs comprise vertical stacks of huge megaslides (interlay-
ered with undisturbed turbidites or hemipelagites) which involve
the Upper Miocene-Quaternary sedimentary succession (Figs. 16
and 18). Such depositional architecture evidences that the margin
has suffered a long history of slope failures, probably as result of
combined modes of gravitational instabilities since the late

5.2. Source to sink and downslope transport processes

In order to better deﬁne the source areas and the overall
transport processes that are at the origin of the megaslides, we
examined (a) the geometry of their headscarps and slide masses,
(b) their internal seismic facies, disruption patterns and related
deformations, as well as (c) their overall distribution and esti-
mates of remobilized volumes. In spite of the similarities between
the two MTCs, each of them has its distinct characteristics with
respect to each MTC. In a general way, PMMC deposits are well
individualized and present relatively more homogeneous patterns
of internal seismic facies than those of the AMC deposits. By
contrast, the rather distinct seismic facies between the basal AM1
and the upper AM2-AM6 equally imply distinct sources and
causes of mass failures.

5.2.1. The Amapa Megaslide Complex
The AMC megaslides spread downslope as radial masses in a
general NeS direction, as essentially unconﬁned slide masses,
since they do not present distal imbricate structures (Figs. 8 and
9). Even if the geometries of their seismic units clearly show
that they are all failed masses, different seismic facies, volumes,
sites of occurrence and ages show that AM1 and AM2-AM6 have
proceeded from different source areas and from eroded material
of even rather distinct sedimentological nature.

5.2.1.1. AM2-AM6 megaslides: structural collapse of the NW ﬂank of
the Amazon fan. AM2 to AM6 headscarps cut into well stratiﬁed
lower slope siliciclastic layers related to the lateral depositional
ﬂank of the Amazon fan, whose gravitational failure constitutes
the source area for the related submarine landslides (Figs. 8 and
9B). These multiple buried slide scars exhibit remarkable spatial
vertical coincidence. Actually, all slide scars occur along sea-bed
ﬂexures of a large proximal faultederotated block which de-
taches in stratigraphic continuity with sections that host AM2 to
AM6, revealing long term instability related to the rotational
deformation of the faulted block along horizon H3 (Fig. 8).
Concerning the mechanism of transport, AM2-AM6 display a

combination of transparent and chaotic facies that slide over basal
ﬂat shear surfaces (except for the base of AM4), which may or may
not bulge up downslope (Fig. 8). These seismic and architectural
attributes indicate translational slides of a high degree of sediment
disruption, such as debris ﬂows containing internal preserved
blocks, thus constituting typical submarine land-slides triggered by
sudden catastrophic events. However, a few of these megaslides’
features are of note:

(i) AM2 and AM5 display dominant transparent facies (Figs. 8
and 10 B and C), suggesting that each one may have been
generated by a single sudden catastrophic event;
(ii) by contrast, the prominent staircase geometry at the base of
AM4 and AM3, and to a lesser extent at the base of AM6
(Figs. 8 and 10 B and C), attests to a much higher erosive
power of their downslope ﬂow, pointing to incremental
incorporation of new material during their emplacement,
and thus to the occurrence of multiple failures and sliding
events at their origin;

(iii) the most recent AM5 and AM6 have incorporated channel-
levee features during their sliding, evidencing the aerial
expansion of the Amazon fan to the NW basin. However,
deformation makes recognition and mapping of the fan more
difﬁcult in the area.

5.2.1.2. AM1: an ancient carbonate platform collapse. The basal AM1
is a quite unique allochthonous mass in the context of the entire Foz
do Amazonas basin. It is the oldest allochthonous mass and cor-
responds to a rather thick and extensive megaslide (Table 1 and
Fig. 8) whose deposition predates the higher siliciclastic input to
deep-water settings known to have occurred from the late
Pliocene-Quaternary onwards (Figueiredo et al., 2009; Gorini et al.,
2014).
Although identiﬁcation of its headscarp area is far less clear than
those of the AM2-AM6 set of megaslides, regional seismic and
stratigraphic analyses support the interpretation that the basal
AM1 was sourced from the collapse of the Upper Paleocene-Upper
Miocene mixed carbonate-siliciclastic platform. This interpretation
is based on the concave-shaped geometry of the shelf-edge of the
central basin, made up of a series of backstepping features carved in
the steep margins of the mixed siliciclastic-carbonate, evidencing
that the platform has frequently failed (Fig. 20). Failure of this
platform produced rock slides like those represented by high
amplitude reﬂections, comparable to the conﬁguration of re-
ﬂections of the carbonate platform itself (Fig. 11B). Besides that, the
highly chaotic to transparent seismic facies that dominates AM1 for
at least 300 km downslope evidences a rather mobile and erosive
nature of the allochthonous mass, probable as a result of a pre-
failed weakening of the platform due to karstiﬁcation during suc-
cessive periods of shelf exposure (see subsection 5.3.1. below). The
North-Northwestern direction of ﬂow, in its turn, was most prob-
ably conditioned by the late Miocene paleo bathymetry which
describes a regional morphological depression dipping north-
westwards (Fig. 20A).

5.2.2. Para-Maranh~ao Megaslide Complex
The PMMC megaslides involve different intervals of the strati-
graphic succession deposited in the basin since the late Pliocene
(last c. 3.8 Ma), all of them being sourced from the same upslope
slide block which detaches along the horizon H3. This slide block is
bounded by two scarps which cut into mid-slope sediments,
standing as distinguishable subregional features between the SE
steep basin slope and the SE ﬂank of the Amazon fan (scarps 1 and 2
in Fig. 13).
All these features support the interpretation that the PMMC's
megaslides have been sourced as individual sediment failures from
the long lasting deformation of the same deformed and faulted
block upslope, which continued to move downslope and to thicken
from 10.5 Ma onwards. As such, PM4 is the only megaslide clearly
sourced from the dismantling of the slide block as reﬂected by the
erosive scarp 2. PM1, PM2 and PM3, on the other hand, are found
some 60 km downslope from the erosive scarp 2 while their
respective slide scars (and scarps) were thoroughly erased by the
continuous collapse of frontal blocks, as well as by the highly
erosive PM4 basal surface, as reﬂected by its irregular staircase
morphology (Fig. 14A).
In a general way, the internal deformation and geometries of
each individual megaslide that compose the PMMC spread down-
slope clearly conﬁned by the Ceara Rise. However, the location and
width of frontally-conﬁned compressional structures evidence that
the reworked deposits have followed distinct ﬂow paths and that
they have been emplaced with different degrees of conﬁnement
(Figs. 12 and 13):

Fig. 20. Possible source area for the AM1 megaslide. (A) Paleo morphological map of the Late Miocene seaﬂoor, before deposition of megaslide AM1, evidencing a regional paleo
bathymetric low SE-NW oriented. (B) Dip-oriented seismic proﬁle illustrating a stair-case morphology on the top of the mixed carbonate-siliciclastic platform evidencing high
erosion (the black dashed line represents the erosive surface).

(i) the radial shapes of PM1, PM2 and PM3 reveal downslope
ﬂow displacement in a general NE-SW direction, dominated
by debris ﬂows containing preserved blocks of variable size
which, coupled with their basal ﬂat shear surface, indicate
the occurrence of failure masses triggered by sudden

catastrophic events (Figs. 12 and 13). But their distal portions
do not spread over the sea-ﬂoor units, having undergone
some degree of fontal conﬁnement exerted by the Ceara Rise,
as indicated by their distal zones of imbricate thrusts of some
5 km wide (Figs. 12 and 14B);

(ii) the thicker PM4, on the other hand, clearly shows a pro-
gressive lost in coherence heading upslope, from a seismic
reﬂection character where it is still possible to recognize the
original stratiﬁcation (thrust sheets) to transparent and
chaotic facies upslope. Further, the prominent staircase ge-
ometry at its base might attest to the erosive power of the
ﬂow, suggesting incremental incorporation of new material
during its emplacement. These facies and the involved high
remobilized volume involved support the interpretation of
PM4 as multiphase slope failures which may probably have
encompassed a large time span and progressively incre-
mental volumes of eroded sediments (Figs. 14 and 19). As a
result, PM4 is the largest megaslide in volume (Table 2),
having been forced to change direction toward the Para-
Maranh~ao basin, due to a strong buttressing effect exerted by
the Ceara Rise, and probably also by the Amazon fan's thick
depositional ﬂank as well (Figs. 12 and 14). Structures
reﬂecting such strong frontal conﬁnement are represented
by the wide zone of thrust structures, some 70 km wide,
similar to the examples described by Frey-Martínez et al.
(2006) in the continental margin offshore Israel. The last
set of thrusts emerges above the general regional datum
deﬁned by the top of the landslide mass, creating a positive
topography of about 100 m high (Figs. 13 and 14B). Similarly,
near its eastern end in the Para-Maranh~ao basin, the land-
slide mass ramps up from about 450 m to 100 m below sea-
ﬂoor exhibiting compressional features that indicate some
degree of buttressing and frontal conﬁnement (thrust
sheets), even if its distal portion spreads over undeformed
sea-ﬂoor units (Fig. 15);
(iii) an ongoing active deformation seems still to occur across the
entire PM4, since its upper inﬁlling stratiﬁed layer is itself
also affected by features such as small irregularities of the
seaﬂoor, normal faults and local folds, clearly indicating that
some degree of gravitational instability has continued, even
after the major remobilization events leading to the mega-
slide have ceased (Fig 14).
5.3. Triggering mechanisms

Slope angle may have an important impact on slope instabilities
but it is not the only indicator of susceptibility to landsliding (e.g.,
Migeon et al., 2006). Slope failure processes are generally triggered
by a combination of several parameters, such as: oversteepening of
the sea-ﬂoor, under-consolidated sediments and rapid sediment
accumulation/sedimentary loading, which may generate an excess
of pore pressure (e.g., Hampton et al., 1996; Biscontin and Pestana,
2006; Nisbet and Piper, 1998; Sultan et al., 2004a, 2004b; Canals
et al., 2004; Bryn et al., 2005; Frey-Martinez et al., 2005; Frey-
Martínez et al., 2006; Moscardelli et al., 2006; Migeon et al., 2006;
Heinrich et al., 2008; Bull et al., 2009; Alves, 2010). Sudden and
high amplitude sea level variations are also understood to be one of
the causes for increasing pore pressure (e.g., Piper et al., 1997;
Maslin and Mikkelsen, 1997; Maslin et al., 2004; Garziglia et al.,
2008). As for carbonate resedimentation, their triggering mecha-
nism and depositional processes remain far less well understood
than their equivalents on siliciclastic margins (e.g., Labaume et al.,
1987; Floquet and Hennuy, 2001, 2003; Eberli et al., 2004; Callot
et al., 2008; Reijmer et al., 2015).
Although we do not deny that sea-ﬂoor oversteepening and
rapid sediment accumulation and sedimentary loading are poten-
tial mechanisms playing a role off the steep margin of the NW and
SE ﬂanks of the Amazon fan, we, nonetheless, identiﬁed across the
entire MTCs two major mechanisms as probably being the most
fundamental triggers for submarine landsliding in the area: the

Gravitational collapse of the mixed carbonate-siliciclastic platform
under its own weight and Sediment slides triggered by block rotation
and/or sliding along the regional H3 decollement for gravity tectonics.

5.3.1. Sediment slide triggered by gravity collapse of the mixed
carbonate-siliciclastic platform
Escarpments in carbonates are normally primarily produced by
a combination of aggradational growth and erosion, arising from
the ability of carbonate platforms to construct very steep slopes and
from the erosional processes that affect these slopes (Eberli et al.,
2004). We interpret that the AM1 was triggered by the gravita-
tional collapse of the mixed carbonate-siliciclastic platform under
its own weight. However, making it much more susceptible to
failure and collapse, the dismantling of the hard carbonate platform
would probably occur after its subaerial exposure provided favor-
able conditions for karstiﬁcation processes (Crevello and Schlager,
1980; Schlager, 2005). Within such a context, a few scenarios of
preconditioning factors may be proposed to explain the collapse
process of the carbonate platform:

(i) During the Serravallian-Tortonian regression (around c. 11.8
Ma) the sea level fell ~100 m below the current sea-level
(Haq et al., 1987). The resulting shelf exposure and erosion
may quite probably have promoted a weakening of the
Miocene carbonate platform, turning it into a rock type more
susceptible to gravitational collapse and to a higher degree of
sediment disruption, resulting thus in mass ﬂows. Such as-
sumptions are also supported by information provided by
Wolfﬁand Carozzi (1984), who, after analyzing core samples
from 18 wells drilled throughout the Amapa Formation,
pointed out that the uppermost Early to Mid-Miocene
sequence of the carbonate platform “shows the most
intense generation of secondary porosity and of dolomiti-
zation …” and that it “… is characterized by the widespread
occurrence of vuggy to channel porosity”;
(ii) as the global sea-level rose again between 11.8 Ma and 10.5
Ma (Haq et al., 1987), it is possible that the distal shelf may
have been drowned again and that the water column may
have overloaded an already fragile shelf. Then, at some point
the platform became weak enough to collapse under its own
weight;
(iii) but the shelf seems to have resisted during most of the 10.5
Ma sea level rise, since the condensed section depicted by
horizon H3 is at places strongly eroded by the AM1 down-
slope ﬂow (Figs. 8 and 11). Such temporal correlations make
it clear that the central-northwestern carbonate platform
collapsed only after the cessation of the carbonate sedi-
mentation (~9.5 Ma). Thus, it is possible that the 9.2 Ma sea-
level fall exposed again the distal shelf to further weathering;
(iv) ﬁnally, seismicity (especially along the Saint Paul) cannot be
excluded as a complementary driving force for the collapse of
an already undermined carbonate shelf, including fault
rupture-induced sliding. A map of historical earthquakes on
the Brazilian Margin compiled by Assumpç~ao (1998) shows
different magnitude epicenters (up to 5 in magnitude)
which follow the lineation of the neighboring Romanche
Fracture Zone. We then hypothesize that such magnitude of
seismicity could have acted as a potential trigger for insta-
bility, especially if additional weakening factors such as
karstiﬁcation had preconditioned the slope for failure.

5.3.2. Sediment slides triggered by block rotation and/or sliding
along the regional H3 decollement for gravity tectonics
Across both the AMC and PMMC, the base of the slide for the

upslope source area of, respectively, the set of megaslides AM2-
AM6
and
PM1-PM4
correlates
laterally
with
the
regional
condensed section depicted by the horizon H3 (Figs. 8 and 13). This
correlation evidences that the impermeability and ﬂuid over-
pressure of the upper decollement for gravity tectonics in the
Amazon fan, in the central portion of the Foz do Amazonas basin,
have also induced the instability and failure of sediment layers on
the NW and SE ﬂanks of the Amazon fan (Fig. 20):

(i) across the AMC, AM2 to AM6 were all triggered in similar
ways. Their slide scars were all triggered in response to
structurally-induced sea-bed ﬂexures of the large proximal
faultederotated
block,
which
experienced
deformation
induced by overpressure conditions along the decollement
level H3. This proximal faultederotated block is itself
partially detached from the upslope continuous scarp A, as
low angle faults detaching along H3 (Figs. 8B and 9B). And
yet, excess of pore water ﬂuid pressure still seems to occur
along horizon H3, as depicted by the inversed polarity of its
associated reﬂection signal (Fig. 8A). All these features sup-
port the interpretation of a rotated block that has been var-
iably folded
and
faulted during
its
displacement
and
downslope sliding along H3 since 1.8 Ma (age of the dated
horizon beneath the AM2). Under such conditions, exten-
sional deformation of the entire sedimentary package above
H3 was accommodated by a combination of proximal
extension and rotation along listric faults and sediment
disruption along the seaward limbs of the rotated block
(Fig. 8B). The reason why the NW portion of the basin did not
produce a typical gravity tectonic nappe (upslope extension
linked to downslope compression) may quite probably be
explained by the local steep sea-ﬂoor. The high gradient
slopes (in the range of 5e6) which occur along the concave
upward basal decollement in the head area of the AMC
(Fig. 6A) may have made the slope more unstable, preventing
the deposition of thicker sediment succession in stable
conditions and thus favoring a higher frequence of sudden
block deformation. This structural pattern led, in its turn, to
more catastrophic and successive disruption events of sedi-
ment layers, instead of to a cumulative downslope stress
capable of being accommodated by distal compression
across thicker sedimentary series;
(ii) in a similar way to the AM2-AM, the PMMC megaslides are
all sourced from the same upslope deformed block, which
has equally detached and moved downslope apparently
induced by overpressure conditions along the decollement
level H3. Here again, an excess of pore water ﬂuid pressure
still seems to occur along the upslope portion of the horizon
H3, as depicted by the inversed polarity of its associated
reﬂection signal (Fig. 14A). However, by contrast, the upslope
PMMC block seems to have experienced a dominant down-
slope
translational
movement,
induced
by
the
basal
decollement that exhibits a more regular morphology. As a
consequence, multistage deformation of the entire sedi-
mentary section above H3 also took place from 3.8 Ma on-
wards (age of the dated horizon beneath PM1). Deformation
of the sliding block is accommodated by widespread normal
faulting that gave rise to successive frontal block slide-offs
which promoted a much higher degree of sediment disrup-
tion when compared to the rotated block that sources the
AMC megaslides.
6. Conclusions

out in the present study evidence a long history of slope instability
and sediment failure on the NW and SE ﬂanks of the Amazon fan,
Foz do Amazonas basin. Our main results revealed that mass-
transport processes have multiple implications for the basin's
stratigraphic record, as well as for explotation strategies:

(a) recurrent failure masses are recorded as large-scale MTCs,
the
Amapa
Megaslide
Complex
(AMC)
and
the
Para-
Maranh~ao Megaslide Complex (PMMC), involving individual
volumes of allochthonous masses of up to c. 24,000 km3.
Some of these failure masses are highly mobile and erosive,
capable of travelling long downslope distances, which im-
plies a great power of deformation and/or destruction of the
original depositional architecture and stratigraphy of the
basin;
(b) successive subaerial exposures and karstiﬁcation processes
of a mixed carbonate-siliciclastic platform favored its gravity
collapse during the late Miocene-early Pliocene, generating a
basal carbonate slide (AM1) which occurs only in the AMC,
since it spreads out preferentially across the central-
northwest basin, conditioned by the paleo bathymetry of
the period;
(c) most megaslides of these MTCs are siliciclastic in nature,
sourced from sea-bed deformations generated by multistage
rotation or the sliding of large upslope blocks (from 30 to
60 km wide). Blocks deformation was triggered by ﬂuid
overpressure along a regional Upper Miocene condensed
section,
horizon
H3,
which
also
acts
as
the
regional
decollement level for gravity tectonics in the basin;
(d) ﬂuid overpressure conditions along H3 does not seem to
have been attained synchronously throughout the basin. In
the case of the PMMC sufﬁcient overpressure capable of
triggering sediment slide seems to have been attained from
the Early Pliocene onwards; in the case of the AMC over-
pressure conditions seems to have been attained later on,
from the mid Pleistocene onwards;
(e) the conditions for structurally-induced slope instability
generated by the regional decollement level H3 are still pre-
sent across the MTCs. The reﬂector of high amplitude nega-
tive
polarity
that
characterizes
H3
indicates
that
the
potential for similar large scale sediment failures continues
to exist in the basin.
